ResponsesInList.Title: Wouldn't it be "loverly."
ResponsesInList.Text: We are a relatively new online specialty school with over 450 members located all over the world. What we would like to be able to do is create global groups of members from the membership list. Let's call the first group "From New Jersey" and install all members from New Jersey into this group. Then when we need to assign students to a particular class, we simply install the group. If there is 1 member or 150 members, the entire group gets assigned the role. As an additional example: We have 15 instructors. Create a global group called "Instructors" which has all the instructors or just those chosen. Then when in the classroom, under "Assign roles" there could be two listings; all members and all global groups. Then by choosing either an individual or a group, the system installs them. This procedure could save time and energy. So, What'ch think? Harvey

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wouldn't it be "loverly."
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Harvey A few things came to mind while reading your post. Perhaps the easiest I can think of is to use the meta-course functionality to manage the enrolments of your groups - yours would be scenario 2 where you have a (probably hidden) course for each group (eg "From New Jersey") of students then individual meta-courses for each required class. The Meta-course functionality needs to be enabled at site level and works by filtering the enrolments from any child courses (the 'From New Jersey' course) to the meta-course/s (the required class courses). I hope this helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wouldn't it be "loverly."
ResponsesInList.Text: Teresa, Thank you for your reply. Unfortunately it doesn't solve our problem. We have approximately 450 members from all over the world, on our site. Let's say that 20 or so individuals from one area get together and form a "Study Group." And let's say that we have 30 different classes that we teach on line. This study group purchases access to class number 1 for "X" dollars. When we receive notice that a Study Group has purchased the course a single user (or the group name), the one who paid for the course will log in and project the course material via a projector and everyone within the group learns together. When the students are ready to take the exam, the teacher/administrator goes to the exam room for this course and assigns the role of student to the group. The role assignment within the classroom/course, recognizes the entry is a group then adds the individuals from the group to the course. Imagine the amount of time it would take to add 50 students to a particular course and then to do it again a few weeks later for another course, then again and again. Look at the amount of time that would be saved if the software could do it directly from the global group; create the global group once and use it where ever an individual can be used. Then as each individual passes the exam, remove them from the course after recording their results. To create a global group: Add new user to "List of Users" if the individual isn't already a member. Then from "Site Administration/Users/Accounts" and below "Add a new user" have another item called "Add a new Group." The group item should contain the same items as an individual; name, password etc. Once the group is created, the window opens to list all groups and all members. Members can be added or removed from the groups here as well. The teacher/administrator then chooses the group and clicks all the members who are to be part of the group. Members can be in more than one group. As far as logging in to the site, the name of the group and its password will be like an individual logged in. That way any member of the group can initiate the log in and then the group can purchase a class or classes. The only difficulty that I see from a programming stance it the possibility that two or more groups is placed into the same classroom and a user happens to be in both groups, therefore showing two instances within the classroom of the same person. Not being familiar with open source, but having been a computer programmer for many years, I don't believe the coding could be all that difficult. True, additional items will need to be added to the DB (Groups and the membership within) plus coding to test for duplicates but "Wouldn't it be Loverly?"

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wouldn't it be "loverly."
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Harvey Perhaps the Site Wide Groups coming up in 2.0 would work, MDL-11826 ?? The Roadmap suggests this requires funding... Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wouldn't it be "loverly."
ResponsesInList.Text: Teresa, That information is what I was looking for. Now, I guess we need to wait until the bugs are worked out and it can be implemented. I'm sure the implementation will cost a few $ to compensate for the effort involved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Disable Front Page

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Disable Front Page
ResponsesInList.Text: All the suggestions above are OK, but do not necessarily meet your need. The easiest and simplest way to do that I suggest is to create a new Role called, say, Staff. then add in the "View Hidden Courses" permission . To do that, go to Administration Menu > Users > Permissions > Define Roles  and click the "Add New Role button". Select the Authenticated User Role as the archetype, and just edit permissions. Assign that Role to all Teachers on the Front Page  and that will meet your need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Login/index.php Slowing Down Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone. Our Moodle 2.6 is sometimes very fast and sometimes extremely slow. We have very few students enrolled due to the very slow performance of the site, so I don't think the problem is linked to actual demand on the site. We previously were using Moodle 1.8, and it was generally pretty fast. We just recently upgraded. I don't know a lot about coding, but our host (Bluehost) said that the login/index.php file seems to be the big culprit. Could you all help with some suggestions of things to check for or possible problems. I thought that perhaps I have a security problem with the location of some key files, so perhaps there is some bot or alien force trying to attack the site? Any help is much appreciated. Tony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Login/index.php Slowing Down Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: You will struggle to run Moodle on a shared host like BlueHost. I would suggest: Moodle very fast - other Bluehost customers websites are quiet Moodle very slow - other Bluehost customers websites are very busy login.php does not do anything too demanding, caching can make a big difference in Moodle 2.6. as for bots, best thing you can do is add a robots.txt file to de index it from search engines.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Login/index.php Slowing Down Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Jez H. I'm not sure what you mean by your suggestion. What is it that you suggest I do (if anything) regarding the problem? You mentioned caching but I'm not sure if there is a related suggestion for that as well? Thanks In advance for any clarification you might offer. Tony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Login/index.php Slowing Down Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Tony, it's hard to comment based on the information you have supplied.  How fast is fast how slow is slow, how many people are logging in? is it 10, 20 100 etc. Later versions of Moodle deliver much more functionality and so require more hardware, something that some Google searches on Moodle performance comparison will help with. However one thing is for certain, the performance of code on shared hosting such as Bluehost will vary according to what other people are doing on the same machine. So if another user of that web space suddenly gets popular by having a page linked on Slashdot (or whatever) all bets on performance is off for everyone else on that machine. It might be nothing to do with the version of Moodle and everything to do with some other user of the web space getting a big surge in hits. This would explain why the performance varies.  I use very cheap hosting (£GBP 50 per year) and the performance is generally fine for about 20 users, but I am entirely aware that sometimes the performance might drop to unusable and that is the cost of cheap. Touch wood this has rarely happened.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Login/index.php Slowing Down Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you. I upgraded to Bluehost's "Pro" server for a slight increase in cost ($35 per year) and it solved the problem. Everything is lightning quick now. Thanks for your help and suggestions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everybody, We are running Moodle with 2 webservers behind a load balancer that attacks one database server . We upgraded of Moodle version from **** to **** with Moodle sessions handled by the database. Since this migration, from time to time, one webserver unexpectedly consumes all the connections to the database. When it occurs, a "show full processlist" mysql command shows that no sql requests are made by any connections. Moodle is then blocked and the error shown is "too many connections to the database". Our max allowed connection is set to 200. Because the moodle cron scripts are executed only on one webserver, we can exclude them as being the cause. We are thinking that the handling of the sessions can be one possibility. Do you have any track or ideas about this issue ? Thanks a lot !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Sessions will certainly add to this. are you using db persistence, if so try turning it off: $CFG->dbpersist = false;

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Thank's for the reply. the db perstitence is false in the config.php file. The issue is due to something with the guest account session. Thanks for all David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: I've never heard of version **** but I bet the left hand **** is <=2.3 and the right hand **** is >=2.4. Am I right?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Your right hand was right, our Moodle version is Moodle 2.5.1+ (Build: 20130712). One expample of the problems, is that when it occurs, the  show full processlist many lines SELECT GET_LOCK('moodle-mdl_-session-46671616', 120), and when i check the session id 46671616, it's the user id 2 (guest). Any guess. Thanks in advance Have a nice day.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Still mystified why your versions were secret. It just makes it a pain to provide a sensible answer. However... Don't store sessions in the database on a load-balanced system. What you *need* to do is to set up a dedicated cache and configure the MUC (introduced in 2.4) to use it. Most people use memcached. It's the only way of getting acceptable performance out a load-balanced configuration >=2.4

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, Thanks for the reply. I'll try it. I put the sessions in the Database , after a technical audit, and the advices of Moodle experts. Have a nice day. David Bréchet

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle consumes all mysql connections
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh no, not "Moodle experts" (I hope it wasn't me!!). The situation for caching and hence sessions changed considerably with the introduction of the MUC in 2.4. The setup is now quite critical on load-balanced systems. Unless your shared moodledata area is on very fast storage - and it won't be - you're probably finding that your page load time is very slow. You'll be happy to hear that a proper memcached setup will magically fix that too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Invisible students!
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure whats happening here but when students login to their course from one pc in particular I do not 'see' them - their activity does not register in activity reports. This is a recent phenemenon as I did not have this difficulty in the past from the pc in question. The student accounts are fully functional and if students use a different pc their activity is visible. Does anyone know why this is happening and what I can do to resolve it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Invisible students!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, Does anybody know whats happening here? What are the possible reasons why activity on a particular pc might not register in activity reports?
